comment:
This game was published only in 1900, in the chess column of the
newspaper "Niva", with a curious introduction by Chigorin. He wrote:
"Sometimes may happen that a chess game is repeated from the first move to the
last one. It is possible when an unexperienced player in the opening play some
natural- and good-looking move. Indeed such moves drive him to a defeat. One
of such games will be now shown to you. The following opening is very common
in amateur practice, and my opponent, an enthusiastic amateur has played it
four times against me." Chigorin does not tell us if there was a fifth time
where his opponent, convinced by the previous four kicks, found the right
continuation. I think this player should be remembered as "Knorr the
tenacious".

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4
comment:
A mistake. Even losing a tempo by retreating the Bishop in e3 was more
convenient. (Chigorin)

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 g5
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 g5 8. Bg3 h5
comment:
Double excl
amation mark!! Chigorin follows the same moves as the famous game
Dubois-Steinitz played in London in 1862, so proving his interest in chess
literature at that time.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 g5 8. Bg3 h5 9. Nxg5
comment:
With this move instead, his opponent proves
himself naif and little prepared. In fact now the next moves seem to be forced
for White. Perhaps it was better to defend himself with

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 g5 8. Bg3 h5 9. Nxg5 h4 10. Nxf7 hxg3 11. Nxd8 Bg4
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. d3 Nf6 5. O-O d6 6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 g5 8. Bg3 h5 9. Nxg5 h4 10. Nxf7 hxg3 11. Nxd8 Bg4 12. Qd2 Nd4 13. Nc3 Nf3+ 14. gxf3 Bxf3
comment: White resigns. Mate in five is inevitable.
